C I R C U L A R   NO.  30 / 2005 
 
 
Subject: 
Security procedures for commercial (non-chartered) helicopters operations. 
 
 
In order to adequately address real vulnerabilities and to mitigate varying threat levels, the following 
security measures shall be applied by all concerned:- 
 
2. 
Aircraft:  In order to prevent unauthorized use of aircraft, the operator will take steps corresponding 
to specific type of aircraft to secure it when unattended.  Pilot should employ multiple methods of securing 
their aircraft to make it as difficult as possible for an unauthorized person to gain access to it. 
 
2.1 
Some basic methods of securing an aircraft include:- 
 
• 
Ensuring that door locks are consistently used to prevent unauthorized access or tampering with the 
aircraft. 
• 
Using keyed ignition where appropriate. 
• 
Storing the aircraft in a hangar, if available, and locking hangar doors. 
• 
Using an auxiliary lock to further protect aircraft from unauthorized use.  Commercially available 
options for auxiliary locks include locks for propellers, throttle, and tie-downs. 
• 
Ensuring that aircraft ignition keys are not stored inside the aircraft. 
 
3. 
Pre-embarkation security checks:  Any person conducting a commercial (non-chartered) 
helicopter operation shall conduct a search of the aircraft before departure and shall screen all passengers, 
crew members and other individuals, and their baggage before boarding, in accordance with the security 
procedures given in Section 3.1 below. The baggage will be matched with the occupants before taking it on 
board as per the laid down procedure. Unmatched baggage shall not be carried in the flight. 
 
Note: 
If emplaning of passengers is done through security hold area of passengers terminal of an 
operational airport, the passengers and their cabin baggage shall be subjected to pre-embarkation security 
checks by ASG/ APSU as per the procedure prescribed by BCAS Circular No. 23/2005 dated 11.7.2005. 
 
3.1 
Pre-embarkation security checks when emplaning of passengers is done from a non-
operational airport or from an area other than security hold area of a passenger terminal of an 
operational airport. 
 
The following pre-embarkation security procedure shall be followed by the helicopter operator:- 
 
3.1.1 
 
Screening of passengers shall be done by means of: 
 
(a) 
Hand Held Metal Detector and/ or 
(b) 
Pat Down search or, 
(c) 
By combination of both the above means.
2:
Pat down search of person will be carried out whenever screener deems it necessary . However, 
atleast one out of 4 persons will be subjected to pat down search on a continuous random basis. 
 
3.1.2 
 
Screening of baggage will be done as below: 
 
(a) 
100% manual hand search; and/  or 
(b) 
X-Ray examination accompanied by manual hand search on continuous random basis 
where the percentage of such search shall not be less than 10% of the total bags in a flight. 
 
4. 
Security measures during dis-embarkation of the passengers at an operational airport:- 
 
4.1 
All passengers, crew members and other individuals along with their baggage shall be deplaned into 
a designated non-sterile area of an operational airport.  Duty Officer in the ATC will direct the 
aircraft to the above area and at the same time inform ASG/APSU about it. 
4.2 Chief Airport Security Officer will ensure that arriving persons from the aircraft do not trespass into 
sterile area of the airport. 
 
4.3 
In case there is no designated non-sterile area at an operational airport for deplaning of the 
passengers and the passengers are deplaned in sterile area, the following security measures shall be 
taken to prevent mixing of such passengers with security cleared passengers of the other commercial 
flights:- 
4.3.1 
Chief Airport Security Officer shall provide necessary security coverage so that passengers 
disembarking into sterile area of the airport do not mix-up with security-cleared passengers 
of commercial flights. 
4.3.2 
Duty Officer in the ATC shall inform APSU/ASG about arrival of a general aviation 
flight/chartered flight.  On receipt of this information, the Chief Airport Security Officers 
will send armed escort to reach the aircraft before deplaning of the passengers.  
4.3.3 
If there are more than one parking bays at an airport, the aircraft will be parked in a bay 
other than the one used for parking of commercial flights.  In case there is only one parking 
bay, the ATC will ensure that when a scheduled commercial aircraft is parked on the apron, 
general aviation/chartered aircraft is parked in a corner of the apron. 
4.3.4 
The armed escort of APSU/ASG will escort the passengers of  the aircraft to the land side 
of the airport.  APSU/ASG will ensure that dis -embarking passengers do not mix-up with 
the security cleared passengers/employees in the airside.  
4.3.5 
The dis-embarking occupants will be transported under escort to the land side of the airport 
through a designated gate so that mix-up with security cleared passengers/employees in the 
air side is avoided.  In case, the number of passengers is large, the airport operator shall 
arrange for a suitable vehicle to carry the passengers to the land side of the airport.  
Likewise, the cargo/baggage from the aircraft shall also be transported under escort to land 
side. 
 
The above circular will be implemented with immediate effect. 
 
(R.C. Tayal) 
Commissioner of Security (Civil Aviation)
